title: Were William the Conqueror and his descendants related to King Alfred the Great? - Quora

response.answer_text: William the Conqueror was not a descendant of Alfred the Great. He was related, of course, but not through common ancestors who are traceable through records. If I had to guess, I’d say their most recent common ancestor was an unknown and unknowable 3rd to 5th century warlord who led Frankish/Saxon pirate raids in the post-Roman Channel. One of these could easily have left descendants in 1) the families who would later become William’s Breton and Frankish ancestors and 2) the families who would become Alfred’s Anglo-Saxon ancestors. William’s only politically important relationship to Alfred was that in 1066 his first cousin once removed on his mother’s side was Edward the Confessor—one of only two living male-line descendants of Alfred. William’s claim was that Edward chose him as heir, and he conquered based on that claim. As for William’s descendants, however, all were descendants of Alfred the Great. That is, if we assume William the Bastard—same man (not his preferred name)—had no illegitimate children of his own. He didn’t acknowledge any, and most genealogists doubt the most commonly claimed one—William Peverel. So, William the Conqueror’s eight known children were all born to his wife Matilda of Flanders, who was a descendant of Alfred the Great through one line. So Alfred the Great was William the Conqueror’s great-great-great-great-great-grandfather-in-law. Alfred the Great, King of England m. Ealhswith Ælfthryth m. Baldwin II, Margrave of Flanders Arnulf I, Count of Flanders m. Adele of Vermandois Baldwin III, Count of Flanders m. Matilda of Saxony Arnulf II, Count of Flanders m. Rozala of Italy Baldwin IV, Count of Flanders m. Ogive of Luxembourg Baldwin V, Count of Flanders m. Adele of France Matilda m. William I, King of England -- all of his descendants -- Starting with a few of the grandchildren, many of William’s descendants kept on accumulating additional lines of ancestry to Alfred. But they all already had at least one.

William isn’t related to Alfred in the sense of ‘sharing blood’, or William being a direct descendant of Alfred’s. William’s children however were related to Alfred There are also several links between the House of Normandy and the House of Wessex that I will mention. William’s great-great aunt was Emma of Normandy. Emma married Æthelred, King of England, who was the great-great grandson of Alfred. William’s wife was Matilda of Flanders she the great(x5) granddaughter of Alfred. This means that William and Matilda’s children, King William II and King Henry I were the great(x6) grandchildren of Alfred. Henry I further linked the line of the House of Normandy to that of the House of Wessex by marrying Matilda of Scotland, she may have been the daughter of King Malcolm III of Scotland, but she was also great(x5) granddaughter of Alfred and the great granddaughter of Edmund Ironside ,King of England. So this means that their daughter, Matilda, is related to Alfred on both were fathers and mothers side. The rest of the Monarchs of England are all descended from Matilda, obviously included her son Henry II, who went on the become one of England’s greatest Kings  Henry II, Great grandson of William the Conquerer and the great(x8) grandson of Alfred the great. Henry II is considered by some to be England’s greatest king
